awd_titl_txt: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Nonlocally Connected Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The perception of the world by the brain is governed both by the external stimuli that it receives, by its constant ongoing activity, and by its prior experience. The ongoing activity is formed by the interaction of the millions of cells that comprise the brain and that sit in a delicately balanced state in order to respond quickly and sensitively to the rapidly changing world. These cells do not form random patterns, but rather produce patterned activity such as waves and rhythms that can form the precursors to complex behaviors such as speaking and walking.  This ongoing and evoked behavior is carefully controlled by a balance of positive (excitatory) and negative (inhibitory) influences. The loss of this balance can disrupt normal behavior and lead to diseases such as epilepsy and schizophrenia. This research project uses mathematical models of the nervous system to provide a way to test hypotheses about brain activity put forth by experimentalists and to suggest new experiments based on the predictions of these models. In addition the project will also provide research training opportunities for graduate students.
 
Ongoing activity in the nervous system and how it impacts sensory and other inputs is the subject of much recent experimental activity. In particular, it is clear that the intrinsic interactions between neuronal circuits in absence of inputs can have a strong impact on how the system responds to incoming stimuli even at the large-scale cognitive level. This project will apply nonlinear dynamics methods to problems in theoretical neuroscience dealing with this question. Various forms of spatiotemporal activity, including spatially localized activity, oscillations, and propagating waves, are observed experimentally. There is now a good deal of evidence that the oscillatory activity that is ubiquitously found in the brain is not synchronized, but, rather, takes the forms of propagating waves and other types of spatiotemporal dynamics. The research will use mathematical models to study neurons that are connected to each other through nonlocal, spatially extended connections. The models of these networks involve nonlocal interactions leading to integro-differential equations. The project aims to develop new techniques for the analysis of such nonlocal equations, including novel perturbation methods, dimension reduction methods, and techniques for localizing the operators.

Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

Many biological systems are able to produce rhythmic output in order to govern simple behaviors such as locomotion, breathing, and even more complex ones including speech and interpreting inputs from the external world.  These rhythms are organized in patterns which can often be seen in the electrical activity measured in the brain. Bard Ermentrout and his students use computational and mathematical models to understand how these patterns are produced and how they may be useful in generating the above types of behavior.  Their models typically consist of individual units that are intrinsically rhythmic and are connected to each other in some type of large network.  One of the most common types of patterns is synchronization where every element in the network turns on at the same time.  Synchrony can be desired, for example, in the case of fireflies, but in other cases it is pathological, for example, in seizures and Parkinson's disease.  Not all rhythmic patterns are synchronized, rather, they can be organized into more complex structures such as spiral waves, and propagating waves.   The latter can be used to convey information, say, from one part of the brain to another.

One of the most astonishing displays of synchronous rhythmic behavior is the collective flashing of certain firefly species. In a paper with an undergraduate student and a colleague, Ermentrout described a mathematical model which explains the pattern of flashing in populations of Photinus carolinus, a firefly species native to the Eastern United States. (see image).  They found conditions on the number of insects, how much they moved, and how regular each individual was such that the population was able to maintain a synchronous flashing pattern.

Spiral or rotating waves have been observed in electrical recordings of human brains and are believed to be important in consolidating memories as the waves are most often seen during sleep. With a PhD student, Ermentrout developed a mathematical model that mimics the brain's connectivity and showed under what conditions spiral waves could emerge.  They showed how certain parameters could lead to different spiral wave shapes and even how they could result in the destruction of the spiral waves (see image).

Information from one area of the brain to others is carried by a wave of activity that is generated from the strong feedback connections of excitatory neurons.   In order to prevent explosive activity (like seizures), this activity is tightly controlled by strong inhibitory feedback. This feedback must be carefully balanced in order to prevent seizures but also to allow the activity to be transferred. In a collaboration with an experimental neuroscientist, Ermentrout and his PhD student developed a novel model thgat is able to explain how such balance can be achieved.  This work has implications for both normal sensory processing and for pathological behavior, like seizures. (See image)
